dlgPart.npc_text:
You see an old, grey-haired man with watery and nearly colorless eyes.
“Need some stitching or bone-setting? Come closer, I can barely see you from here.”
“Need some stitching or bone-setting? Come closer, I can barely see you from here.”
“Charge?” says the old man looking surprised. “We don’t charge for anything around here. That’s the beauty of this life, ain’t it?”

“Stop your jesting,” snaps the old man. “You know damn well what I mean. When you sign up, you trade in your worry and your uncertain future for a sword and shiny armor and everything else that comes with it. From that point on you never go hungry again, nor will you need for anything – including direction. You’ll be well fed, looked after, and told what to do.
“I joined when I was a young lad, working on my father’s farm along with my brothers. Now that’s a hard life, full of uncertainties. I signed up with the Guards the first chance I got and never looked back. My brothers are long dead, the farm’s gone, but I’m still around.”

“A natural aptitude, you might say. Every soldier knows how to clean and stitch a wound after a battle but me, I’ve always had a special knack for it. Before you know it, everyone was coming to see me to stitch their sorry hides. I always did it nice and clean. Knew which herbs to use too. Soon, the legatus, may he rest in peace now, came to see me work and told me that from that point on my job was to stitch and mend. Traded the sword for a needle, you might say.”

dlgAnsw.text: “I have to admit, this camp isn’t what I expected.”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“Too dull and quiet for you? The men come here to rest after months of fighting. Of course, many would prefer a proper drinking house... Come to think about it, a whorehouse wouldn’t hurt either. My best days might be behind me now, but it would please the eyes, that’s for damn sure.
“Paullus won’t hear none of it though, so the point is moot. He’s all about discipline, so no drinking, no whoring, no gambling.”
“Of course they do,” grins the old man. “Paullus aint a man to ask twice. It took a decimation to get this point across but nobody’s drinking now. Not here at least.”
“Decimation,” nods the old man. “You know, draw lots, kill every tenth man. Do they have a different name for it where you come from?”

The old man looks at you again to make sure you’re serious, then shrugs.
“Suppose you give an order and your men refuse to do it. What are you gonna do? Give them a talking to? Chain them? Kill them all? No. You split them in groups of ten and let them draw lots. The poor bastard who draws the lucky one is killed and his brethren are the ones who have to do the killing.
“If an entire cohort fucks up, it might take a while as that’s what, fifty people to kill? Well, this way you lose only ten percent of your soldiers, but the rest will do whatever it takes to avoid drawing lots again and butchering their own.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Interesting. Alright, you can fix me up now.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I did, back when he was a centurion. He always had a problem doing what he was told, but he was a good soldier, so they always let it slide and look at the results. To tell you the truth, I knew there was going to be trouble when Paullus sent him to Teron, but it wasn’t my place to say anything.”
“Well, if you want your orders followed, why would you send someone who has a problem following orders?”

dlgAnsw.text: “Interesting. Alright, you can fix me up now.”

dlgPart.npc_text:
When it comes to healing, the old man sticks with three basic techniques: cutting, burning, and stitching. Clearly, what was good for the cavemen is good enough for him. Occasionally, he spits out something what looks like chewing tobacco and shoves it in the wound, saying that a bit of herb will do the body good.
In the end he manages to stop the bleeding without causing any permanent damage or disfigurement and patch up your wounds. If you didn't know any better, you'd think you're as good as new.
